author: matt.nelson
content:
Hi everyone - the Besu team has written a post-mortem for our Mainnet halting event on January 6th. The details are at the link below:

https://wiki.hyperledger.org/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=117440824

The 1000 foot view is that some create2/self-destruct patterns were being used in a way that exposed a corner case in our state DB implemenation.

author: mariusvanderwijden
content:
Correction 

I'm pretty sure most of you have seen my reddit post by now. 
Since it was getting more attention, 
I decided to run the numbers again and realized that they are pre-shanghai numbers.
The attack relies heavily on behavior that is not possible anymore.
Post-shanghai I get ~250ms on geth (down from 1.3s)
On reth I get ~150ms (down from 6s)
on besu ~2.7s (down from 8.2s) (on a different machine thanks to <@841775421024239688> )
I couldn't get the nethermind numbers unfortunately, but they should also be way less

The current test case I have is not optimal, but should be close to 
the worst case possible under 40MGas.

To reiterate, these numbers are WORST CASE numbers for a specific attack.
These are not in any way indicative of the performance of a client under 
normal conditions.

author: matt.nelson
content: To note this also includes the JVM startup time on Besu, which will impact the overall time result - same with Netherminds VM
